title: Do people actually like csing?
body: I personally don't, which is why I'm a support main. I prefer interacting with the players rather than minions. But I really do want to know if other people find it fun

There was actually a blog about this a while back for something a bit unrelated. Sean Day9 went over what makes a game fun and engaging, and a big difference between RTS and MOBA was the level of interaction from the second you hit the map.

If you take Starcraft 2 for instance, to generate income, you simply build workers and start harvesting minerals. The first several minutes of a game (aside from scouting, or some kind of cheese) is simply placing structures and mining more income. According to their research, this is a turn off for many gamers in this day and age. People like to be engaged, doing something, from the minute the game starts. Enter League.

While the practice of CS'ing may seem monotonous and dull to some, what it really does is create an interaction that keeps the player engaged from the start. You aren't just building a drone and automatically sending him to bring you income, you're actively working to land that last hit and gain a bit more gold every minion. Combine this with having another play in the lane with you, and you've created a style of game that is never dull due to the mechanics of CS'ing, wave manipulation, and the opposing champion. You are always doing something, you are always interacting. 

So overall, in a game like League based off of gold income, I'm of the belief that CS'ing adds a certain value and level of interaction that keeps you engaged in the game from the moment (or shortly after actually) you hit the rift. It is repetitive, it can be hard, or it can just be dull; but overall it seems to be in my mind, a necessity of entertainment value.

You're doing it wrong... the ideal time for harassing your opponent is when A) you are waiting for the next minion to get low enough and B) your opponent is currently trying to last hit a minion.

This is the ideal moment because you can harass without losing cs and without retaliation (if the enemy retaliates, then the trade was even but he lost that cs; if he doesn't retaliate, then he didn't fall back on cs but got harassed for free; there's also a third possibility, where he doesn't retaliate and still misses that cs, but that's just him messing up).

CS'ing is a really important part of the game. It allows champions that need scale for late game to be viable (not currently of course)  against champions that use early game burst to snowball.

Some champions actually rely on it entirely for their poke (e.g. Malzahar) because approaching close enough to do so will result in instant death against most champions.

CS'ing is a really good part of the game that is both tactical and reliable when used by a skilled player correctly.
